documentation.title: Can I waive my constitutional rights?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: e.g. in the EPL ([Eclipse Public License](http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html)) the last statement reads like this.

> Each party waives its rights to a jury trial
>  in any resulting litigation.

Can I waive my fundamental constitutional rights? If that be the case, wouldn't it be possible for a legal entity to coerce or cheat a person into a contract that violates his/her constitutional right/s?

Isn't the law of the land above all (including contracts)? 

Can the law through due process come to conclusion that a person be denied his constitutional rights because he signed a contract that was illegal/unconstitutional in the first place?

This is not a duplicate of these questions

1. [Can I waive my statutory rights?](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/278/can-i-waive-my-statutory-rights)
2. [How can felons be denied Constitutional rights?](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/6981/how-can-felons-be-denied-constitutional-rights)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Actually, the concept "right" means that it can be waived: you may exercise the right, but do not have to. If it is an *obligation*, you can't "waive" the obligation; but the right to free speech does not mean that you must speak, and the right to bear arms does not mean that you must bear arms. You may decline to exercise, or waive, a right.

Sternlight [16 Ohio St. J. On Disp. Resol. 669 (2001\)](http://scholars.law.unlv.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1278&context=facpub) in "Mandatory Binding Arbitration and the Demise of the Seventh Amendment Right to a Jury Trial" partially addresses this (the focus though is on binding arbitration). One thing to note is that the Seventh Amendment does not appear to apply to issues in state court (it is a separate and fascinating question to wonder what parts of The Constitution are incorporated against states, and why). All is not lost for the constitutional question, we just need a different constitution.

By the agreement terms, "This Agreement is governed by the laws of the State of New York". Therefore, New York's Constitution (Article 1 Sect 2\) is also applicable:

> Trial by jury in all cases in which it has heretofore been guaranteed
>  by constitutional provision shall remain inviolate forever; but *a jury
>  trial may be waived by the parties in all civil cases in the manner to
>  be prescribed by law*.

Thus, the right may be waived. Waiver of a right to jury trial is not the same as waiver of the right to trial: what the agreement says is that litigants would have a civil bench trial, where the judge determines whether there was a breach.

In New York, [NY CPLR § 4102](http://law.justia.com/codes/new-york/2012/cvp/article-41/4102) allows parties to waive civil trial by jury (and unlike [California](https://casetext.com/case/grafton-partners-v-superior-court-2)), such waiver terms have been [upheld](http://www.chadbourne.com/sites/default/files/publications/hall%20judge%20smith%20nylj%20reprint%2012%2009.pdf), but the courts have recognized that there is a problem, so it's not always obvious whether such waivers in contracts are legal.

58.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Under New York state law, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding contractual waiver of the right to a jury trial in civil cases?

A) Contractual waivers of jury trials are always enforceable, as the right to a jury trial can be freely waived by parties in any contract.

B) Contractual waivers of jury trials are never enforceable, as they violate the New York State Constitution's guarantee of jury trials in civil cases.

C) Contractual waivers of jury trials are generally enforceable, but courts have recognized potential issues and may scrutinize such waivers on a case-by-case basis.

D) Contractual waivers of jury trials are only enforceable if explicitly authorized by a separate New York statute for each type of civil case.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, New York law (NY CPLR § 4102) allows parties to waive civil trial by jury, and such waiver terms have been upheld by courts. However, the passage also notes that "courts have recognized that there is a problem, so it's not always obvious whether such waivers in contracts are legal." This suggests that while these waivers are generally enforceable, they may be subject to scrutiny and potential challenges on a case-by-case basis. 

Answer A is too absolute, as it doesn't account for potential scrutiny or challenges. Answer B is incorrect because the New York State Constitution explicitly allows for waiver of jury trials in civil cases. Answer D is overly restrictive and not supported by the given information.

documentation.title: What is still considered obscenity in the United States?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I just skimmed the [Wiki article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_obscenity_law) on US obscenity law, and all the cases are from decades back. What would still be considered obscenity today and prosecuted as such?

While my question is general to all cases of obscenity, I'm particularly interested in things that would be considered illegally obscene, but that aren't violations of other laws. For example, images of bestiality would also be illegal for animal abuse. I'm interested in what can still make something obscene without involving other crimes.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: As far as I can tell, the established category of "obscene" material is child pornography, and the most current relevant case is [US v. Williams](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/553/285/#tab-opinion-1962658), 553 U.S. 285\. The relevant law is 18 USC 2252A which refers as a subcase to "an obscene visual depiction of a minor engaging in sexually explicit conduct". Obscenity is not actually a requirement for conviction under the law, it suffices for material to be non\-obscene "child pornography" ([Osborne v. Ohio](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/495/103/), 495 U.S. 103\). Outside of the realm of child pornography laws, there don't appear to be any cases of tenable laws against "obscenity" from the past 25 years. The Miller test ([Miller v. California](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/413/15/), 413 U.S) potentially applies to cases not involving children, but nothing recent clearly establishes a concrete category of prohibited materials.

59.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the context of current U.S. obscenity law, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) All forms of obscene material, including those not involving minors, are actively prosecuted under federal law.

B) The Miller test is the primary standard used in recent obscenity cases not involving minors.

C) Child pornography is the main category of material consistently treated as obscene under current law.

D) Bestiality images are considered obscene solely based on their content, without reference to animal abuse laws.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, child pornography is the most established and consistently prosecuted category of obscene material under current U.S. law. The most recent relevant case mentioned is US v. Williams (2008), which deals with child pornography laws.

Answer A is incorrect because the passage indicates that outside of child pornography, there haven't been notable obscenity prosecutions in the past 25 years.

Answer B is incorrect because while the Miller test potentially applies to non-child-related cases, the passage states that "nothing recent clearly establishes a concrete category of prohibited materials" using this test.

Answer D is incorrect because the question specifically asks about obscenity separate from other crimes, and bestiality would likely be prosecuted under animal abuse laws rather than purely obscenity statutes.
